column2: Meanwhile Dick had dressed with more rapidity than ever before in his life, fully alive to the great dangers that threatened.

column2: But his fear was greatest lest he might lose the precious dispatches that he bore.
column3: But his fear was greatest lest he might lose the precious dispatches that he bore.

column2: For a few moments he did not know what to do.
column3: For a few moments he did not know what to do.

column2: He might take his pistols and fight, but he could not fight them all with success.
column3: He might take his pistols and fight, but he could not fight them all with success.

column2: Then that pleasant flood of cold air gave him the key.
column3: Then that pleasant flood of cold air gave him the key.

column2: While they were still talking he put his saddle bags over his arm, opened the shutter its full width, and dropped quietly to the ground outside, remembering to take the precaution of closing the shutter behind him, lest the sudden inrush of cold startle the Leffingwells and their friends.
column3: While they were still talking he put his saddle bags over his arm, opened the shutter its full width, and dropped quietly to the ground outside, remembering to take the precaution of closing the shutter behind him, lest the sudden inrush of cold startle the Leffingwells and their friends.

column2: It was an icy night, but Dick did not stop to notice it.
column3: It was an icy night, but Dick did not stop to notice it.

column2: He ran to the stable, saddled and bridled his horse in two minutes, and in another minute was flying westward over the flinty road, careless whether or not they heard the beat of his horse's hoofs.
column3: He ran to the stable, saddled and bridled his horse in two minutes, and in another minute was flying westward over the flinty road, careless whether or not they heard the beat of his horse's hoofs.

column2: CHAPTER VIII.
column3: CHAPTER eight.

column2: A MEETING AT NIGHT
column3: A MEETING AT NIGHT

column2: Dick heard above the thundering hoofbeats only a single shout, and then, as he glanced backward, the house was lost in the moonlight.
column3: Dick heard above the thundering hoofbeats only a single shout, and then, as he glanced backward, the house was lost in the moonlight.

column2: When he secured his own horse he had noticed that all the empty stalls were now filled, no doubt by the horses of the young Leffingwells and Kerins, but he was secure in his confidence that none could overtake the one he rode.
column3: When he secured his own horse he had noticed that all the empty stalls were now filled, no doubt by the horses of the young Leffingwells and Kerins, but he was secure in his confidence that none could overtake the one he rode.
